has a one terminal airport. Scheduled flights are available to and from
(Sunday, Wednesday and Friday service only on

. Non-stop flights are offered to Las Vegas, and Los Angeles. Prices start around $200 for a ticket purchased separately, but are much less expensive when combined with flights going through Los Angeles. Some direct weekday flights from Santa Maria to Las Vegas via Allegiant Air can be as inexpensive as $29 each way.  Beginning in November 2012, Alleriant will offer direct flights from Santa Maria to Honolulu, Hawaii.

Air Charter or air taxi is another alternative, where you can catch flights to

for the weekend, or to any large or small airport.  Air charters fly point-to-point, at the departure time, departure airport, and arrival airport of the passengers' choosing.  Prices start around $150 for a seat on flights that might already be going to your destination, or go from $1,000 to $10,000 or more for a custom-chartered flight where you hire the aircraft to fly you directly to your destination, any time you want to go.  On-demand flights, and seats on flights already chartered to/from Santa Maria are offered by

(bus stop is located at the IHOP near 101/Main St). The bus connects with the Pacific Surfliner train in Santa Barbara. There is a train station in the near-by town of Guadalupe served by the Pacific Surfliner Amtrak train (one southbound train from San Luis Obispo stops there in the morning, northbound train from San Diego stops there at night).

There is a Greyhound station at 755 W Cypress Street, and the Greyhound bus also stops at the same IHOP as the Amtrak bus.

is home to one of the first and one of the few still-operating drive-in movie theaters, it is definitely a car town. Highway 101 runs through Santa Maria, as well as California highways 1, 135 and 166. North on 101 takes you through
. Highway 1 is a scenic drive, taken northward it leads you through several small towns eventually connecting with 101 just past
and Vandenberg Air Force Base. Highway 166 west takes you to Guadalupe, and east takes you to the great central valley of
. Highway 135 south takes you to Vandenberg Air Force Base and eventually connect with 101 at
. North will also take you to the 101 near the northern city limits.

, with more coverage during the day, and service ending at 10:15 pm. SMAT has routes all throughout the city. Central Coast Area Transit operates routes between San Luis Obispo and Santa Maria, and riders can connect with other CCAT routes in San Luis Obispo to go further north into San Luis Obispo County. As of 2008 it only costs $2.00 for the 33 mile bus ride from Santa Maria to San Luis Obispo. The Guadalupe Flyer takes you west of Santa Maria through scenic Highway 166 to Guadalupe. There is also the Breeze Bus which has stops in near Vandenburg Air Force Base, and nearby Lompoc. Public transportation in the valley will take you anywhere you want but a car would be best.

content=A huge park with lakes, pony rides, hiking and biking trails, a frisbee golf course, and plenty of grassy lawn space.
is a major shopping mall in Santa Maria, located at the junction of Broadway (Route 135) and Main Street (Route 166). http://www.santamariatowncenter.com

content=Established in 1984, Atari-ya is a Japanese owned and operated restaurant serving the finest authentic Japanese cuisine
to the residents and visitors of the Central Coast.

- an 18 mile stretch of shoreline containing the second-largest coastal dune field in California.  Located west of Santa Maria.
